Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: James, is a true physical bitcoin possible? One where users can trust that the coin holds a certain digital amount. Is it possible to use crypto conditions to create such a thing? For example, a meta ledger that tracks who can unlock an amount from a physical coin. A load and lock kind of mechanism. I put 5 dollars in a 5 dollar denomination coin and locked it. I now have the right to redeem it. I can pass this right to the next public wallet.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: But what if anyone can create and lock coins?

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: They dont all have to look the same

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: Redemption is the meta ledger tracking that you own the coins

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: A DAO

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: or smartcontract of sorts

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: I'm not so technical. I'm just assuming fund can be sent to some type of smartcontract or DAO. They can only be redeemed if the next users public key was switch with the previous users public key (representing a transfer of ownership - like a meta ledger). Its not very efficient. I would imagine, given that you agree a central party is required, that some type of smartcontract or DAO could act as a trusted third party. I'm not sure how but if anyone could think of it it's probably james.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a onetime use privkey could be implemented with CC

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: But would a onetime use private key be useful for a coin that constantly changes hands?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes. put it on the inside of the coin. it requires the coin to be destroyed to reveal the privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: problem is that there wont be a way to prove that it has any actual privkey inside

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is as centralized as you sending a tx to someone else

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the usage of the privkey is validated by the entire network

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: I get what you guys are saying. There will always have to be someone with access to the private key.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: bummer :/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the validity also. the problem is to properly prove there is a privkey inside would be to have a zero knowledge RFID that proves there is a privkey to the pubkey inside

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is no minting here, just putting funds into a privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, in that sense you do need to trust the minting process doesnt reveal the privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and there is a zksnark like way to prove it has a privkey

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and the only way to reveal the privkey is to destroy the coin

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: I understand, so there is no optimal ways yet . Darn, I feel like this would help spread crypto.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: Cheers, thanks for the info guys.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: Yeah, it would be easy for a central party :/

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: @Deleted User https://youtu.be/LK5G5jAzoyk

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: Just learned about this.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: does it prevent the retention of a copy? if not, it seems not having much value

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: But the person that sends the private key would know the private key. In this situation you cannot know the private key until the hardware is damaged in an irreversible way. It acts as true cash until destroyed. It is only one time use though.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: Yes, no one can create a copy since the private key cannot be found until the device is destroyed.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: The one time use (after redemption) and the cost make it not too viable.

Author: rainbro7#4735
Content: I think it's around 40 dollars for 3.

SuperNET is implements that right? BarterDex backend is SuperNET?

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: Okay thanks for this information.

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: Sorry I am kinda lost on the CC part, so I notice in the Komodo repo, there is a CC source, so if I add a new CC like CC_VOTE, will this mean it will create a OP_VOTE opcode and add on the UTXO?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: no

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you make a CC_VOTE, there will be a new CC evalcode of CC_VOTE

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: So CC_VOTE is the contract itself?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you can put it in the libcc.so and make a user defined evalcode. look at ~/komodo/src/cc/cclib.cpp

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the code that validates VOTE evalcode is the "contract"

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so whenever a VOTE utxo is spent, the code associated with the CC_VOTE is invoked and it can do whatever (literally) it needs to in order to say true or false

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: https://docs.komodoplatform.com/cc/index-book-jl.html

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: Thank you, so for this example. https://docs.komodoplatform.com/cc/book-jl/chapter09.html

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: Is `createFunding` a function if we want to make a Dice contract?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the way dice CC was designed, there needs to be "house" funds to bet against. without any such funds, you really cant bet against the house

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the first step is to fund the dice plan

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: by doing various transactions you advance the state and achieve the desired effects

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC are quite a bit different than anything else, so you do need to study the existing examples to see how they achieve their goals

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: faucet CC is one of the simpler ones

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: Okay thanks @jl777c , I was comparing it to Solidity for my paper, since in Solidity you just create a smart contract(based on the language syntax) and run it, in CC I am confused on why it has a implementation in core code and how would a finished contract look like

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC run natively at full speed with total access to all daemon data

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i guess it is like the difference between CPU mining and ASIC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is more work to make an ASIC, but the result is orders of magnitude more efficient

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC is NOT equivalent to solidity

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in fact, theoretically it is possible to make a single solidity CC that would interpret solidity contracts

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC are able to change consensus rules for the blockchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: solidity runs an interpreted language under existing consensus rules

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: once a CC exists, you interact with it by sending CC transactions

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content:
> in fact, theoretically it is possible to make a single solidity CC that would interpret solidity contracts
So basically, if this would be possible we can apply use solidity in creating contracts for KMD?

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: so `faucet.cpp` is the contract at this point?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, once such a CC exists, that would be possible. but considering that we can get things like rogue CC working in a couple weeks there isnt  much need for solidity. also it would be 10x to 100x slower and possibly not viable for any compute intensive things

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: maybe we shouldnt use the word "contract", smart or otherwise

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: CC is a TOTALLY different way of solving the same problem

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it implements constrained transactions with a specific vout type

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and using this, one of the nearly infinite things you can do, is implement what are commonly known as "smart contracts", you could create a smart contract interpreter, you could make a blockchain enforced sudoku too

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: So every addition/modification of the CC you have to rebuild `komodod` and publish daemon updates with new CCs right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there is the libcc.so, which is a dynamic library to make user defined CC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it isnt quite building right, but when it is you can just update libcc.so and komodod would use it

Content: This needs testnet funds to run the conditions right?

Content: I mean CC

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: just normal txfee of 0.0001

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: its just normal tx as far as the rest of the blockchain is concerned

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: So the CC are executed with an RPC call?

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: ```Each Crypto-Conditions contract has its own special address that is known to all, including its private key.```

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: This is a different privkey right?

Author: josephnicholas GMT+8#5904
Content: This is from here: https://komodoplatform.com/crypto-conditions-utxo-based-smart-contracts/

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: globally known privkeys allows funds to be locked in an address and then depending on the rules of the CC to be unlocked by potentially anybody. If possible it is better to not use such as there is only CC validation protecting the funds, but sometimes that is exactly what you need.
